author: timhc22
content: <@!364458974906548225> I've still not been able to quantify exactly what the purpose of this specific channel is, any thoughts on what an appropriate post for this specific channel would be?

author: timhc22
content: say, for example, I was meant to be writing some 'technical content', aimed at explaining ethereum in an easier-to-understand way, would this be a good space for questions about that?

author: pipermerriam
content: Education efforts focused outward.  Topics related to informing people about protocol changes or teaching people about the protocol itself.

author: pipermerriam
content: Yes, if you wrote up an educational piece and wanted to get some ðŸ‘€ on it for review/correctness/whatever this would be a great place for that

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!767574621229678622> is working on an educational website for SSZ, I'll take this as a moment to embarrass him a little, this would be a good channel for him to make his work known and get feedback on it.

author: timhc22
content: without wanting to cause any unnecessary arguments, if <@!478336955378171927> had been asked by an investor: "I don't understand Ethereum, I want to invest to give my money to help grow the protocol, but I don't quite understand where my ROI will come from", as this is not the place for support posts (but that is focussed on educating people outside of the ethereum space), where would be a better place to ask a question like that?

author: timhc22
content: I look forward to seeing <@!767574621229678622> 's site, what does SSZ stand for by the way?

author: timhc22
content: (without wanting to embarrass myself with my lack of knowledge here)

author: sky.cactus
content: I would start with the Ethereum website.  It has links out to other places that help explain things.

author: protolambda
content: Simple SerialiZe https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/dev/ssz/simple-serialize.md

author: pipermerriam
content: Roughly what Micah said.  I typically don't actually know where the best place for people to ask these types of questions is, but it isn't this server.  I get that it's unfortunate.  I'd like to help everyone but I have to be somewhat aggressively strategic with my time (and with everyone else's time on this server).  For example, people regularly email me asking me questions about open source projects that I've written.  I always make them post their question publicly in something like a Github issue because it's not feasible for me to do 1:1 support like that.  It's not feasible for "us" to do individual end-user support that isn't directly tangible to advancing the protocol in this discord.

author: timhc22
content: perfect answer

author: timhc22
content: ah so it is just a function (opcode?) in Eth2.0 for converting to a stream of bytes?

author: pipermerriam
content:
For example, I'll drop this in here.  I think it's on topic ðŸ˜¬  

https://blog.ethereum.org/2021/05/13/core-dev-apprenticeship/

If anyone wants to tweet or otherwise help promote that I'd appreciate the help spreading awareness

author: pipermerriam
content: No, independent of the EVM.  It's a serialization scheme (like CBOR, protobuf, etc)

author: timhc22
content: I was having a chat with someone the other day about the accountability structure within the core dev team, EIPs first go through a peripheral team before hitting the core devs is that correct?

author: timhc22
content: I guess someone would become a peripheral dev before becoming a core dev? (sorry if that is not at all the language you are using over there)

author: sky.cactus
content: If by "peripheral team" you mean "the EIP editors" which is really just a lone madman, then yes.

author: timhc22
content: oh there is only one?

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, yes, if you are interested in doing EIP editing you are welcome to join!

author: sky.cactus
content: Technically there are several, but there is one who does most of the editing.

author: sky.cactus
content: https://discord.gg/QZ9sgXuc to get more information on how to participate in EIP editing.

author: timhc22
content:
For anyone who knows, would this be a decent way to articulate the drawbacks of attacking a PoS network? I'm not completely sure I captured the essence quite well enough:

"In PoS, if caught, an attacker's attack power is reduced by a percentage of their total stake after each unsuccessful attack attempt. As the staked amount gets lower, so does the voting power".
